==Effects and aftermath==
===The Clinton‚ÄìTrump debates=== The release of the tape led to a renewed anticipation towards the [[United States presidential debates, 2016#Second presidential debate (Washington University in St. Louis)|October 9 debate]] between Trump and Hillary Clinton, as it would be the first time for each candidate to directly address the controversy. Less than two hours before the debate began, Trump held a surprise press conference in [[St. Louis]] with [[Paula Jones]], [[Kathleen Willey]], and [[Juanita Broaddrick]], who have [[Bill Clinton sexual misconduct allegations|previously accused Bill Clinton of sexual misconduct]], and [[Kathy Shelton]], a rape victim whose rapist had been represented in the 1970s by Hillary, an appointed [[Public defender (United States)|public defender]]. Describing the conference as his "debate prep", Trump described the women as "courageous" and "victims of the Clintons", with each of the women repeating their grievances with the Clintons.<ref name="PR">{{cite news |last1=Cheney |first1=Kyle |last2=Goldmacher |first2=Shane |title=Trump launches sneak attack ahead of debate |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/10/trump-debate-hypocrites-republicans-229408?lo=ap_c1 |work=Politico |date=October 9, 2016 |accessdate=October 10, 2016}}</ref> At the conference, Trump refused to answer journalists' questions about the ''Access Hollywood'' tape.<ref name="PR" /> Clinton's campaign dismissed the conference as "an act of desperation" and denounced Trump's "destructive race to the bottom".<ref name="PR" /> First Lady [[Michelle Obama]] said referring to the controversy, "It has shaken me to my core in a way that I couldn't have predicted."<ref>{{cite web | last=Kelly | first=Amita | title=WATCH: Michelle Obama Says Trump Comments Have 'Shaken Me To My Core' | publisher=NPR | date=October 13, 2016 | url=https://www.npr.org/2016/10/13/497817419/michelle-obama-trump-comments-have-shaken-me-to-my-core | accessdate=October 18, 2016}}</ref>
During the debate itself, [[debate moderator|co-moderator]] [[Anderson Cooper]] pressed Trump about whether the conversation on the tape meant that Trump had committed sexual assault. Trump said it "was locker room talk" and "I'm not proud of it," and said he wanted to move on to other things, but finally responded "I have not."<ref name=DebateFact>[https://www.npr.org/2016/10/09/497056227/fact-check-clinton-and-trump-debate-for-the-second-time Fact Check: Clinton and Trump debate for the second time], NPR (October 9, 2016).</ref> It was later revealed that Trump had arranged for the women to sit in his family box and that they were to walk into the audience at the same time as Bill and confront him on live TV, but debate officials intervened and prevented the planned stunt from happening.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/10/10/trumps-debate-plan-to-seat-bill-clintons-accusers-in-family-box-was-thwarted/ |title=Trump wanted to put Bill Clinton's accusers in his family box. Debate officials said no. |newspaper=The Washington Post |accessdate=October 11, 2016}}</ref> The [[Associated Press]] later reported that Willey and Shelton had previously been financially compensated by Trump ally [[Roger Stone]] during the campaign.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://apnews.com/bc502cc803854f6aacc50f16d0d049db |title=Sexual assault victim critical of Clinton paid by Trump ally |publisher=Associated Press |accessdate=October 11, 2016}}</ref>
===Assault stories=== Shortly after the story first broke on October 7, Canadian writer [[Kelly Oxford]] posted on Twitter, "Women: tweet me your first assaults. they aren't just stats."<ref>{{Cite tweet|number=784541062119456769|user=kellyoxford|author=Kelly Oxford|title=Women: tweet me your first assaults. they aren't just stats. I'll go first: Old man on city bus grabs my "pussy" and smiles at me, I'm 12.|date=October 7, 2016}}</ref><ref name=":2">See: * {{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/10/11/497530709/one-tweet-unleashes-a-torrent-of-stories-of-sexual-assault|title=One Tweet Unleashes A Torrent Of Stories Of Sexual Assault|publisher=NPR |access-date=October 12, 2016}} * {{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/11/us/politics/sexual-assault-survivor-reaction.html|title=For Many Women, Trump's 'Locker Room Talk' Brings Memories of Abuse|last=Mahler|first=Jonathan|date=October 10, 2016|newspaper=The New York Times|access-date=October 12, 2016}}</ref> Within hours, the tweet had gone viral, receiving thousands of responses, many of them relating to stories of sexual assaults on women. Over 30 million people viewed or replied to Oxford's tweet within a week.<ref name=":2" />
===Response of athletes and coaches=== [[File:Trump Supporters Disgusted by Lewd Tape, But Still in His Corner.webm|thumb|right|250px|News report of voter reactions by [[Voice of America]].]] Numerous professional athletes and coaches rejected Trump's claim that what he said on the tape was "locker room talk", saying that such comments were not normal or acceptable.<ref name=":3">Cydney Adams, [http://www.cbsnews.com/news/professional-athletes-are-not-happy-about-donald-trump-locker-room-talk/ Professional athletes cry foul over Trump's "locker room talk"], CBS News (October 10, 2016).</ref><ref>Adam Howard, [http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/not-lot-love-trump-s-locker-room-defense-n663706 Athletes and Coaches to Donald Trump: Sexual Assault Is Not 'Locker Room Talk'], NBC News (October 10, 2016).</ref><ref>Sean Gregory, [http://time.com/4526039/donald-trump-locker-room-athletes/ Donald Trump Dismisses His 'Locker Room Talk' As Normal. Athletes Say It's Not], ''Time'' (October 10, 2016).</ref> [[Los Angeles Clippers]] head coach [[Doc Rivers]] said, "[If Trump's comments are locker room talk] that's a new locker room for me."<ref name=":4" /> [[Oakland Athletics]] [[pitcher]] [[Sean Doolittle]] tweeted, "As an athlete, I've been in locker rooms my entire adult life and uh, that's not locker room talk."<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" /> [[Kansas City Chiefs]] [[wide receiver]] [[Chris Conley (American football)|Chris Conley]] tweeted, "Just for reference. I work in a locker room (every day) ... that is not locker room talk. Just so you know ..."<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" /> [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] pitcher [[Brett Anderson (baseball)|Brett Anderson]] tweeted, "What kind of fucked up locker rooms has Donald Trump been in ..."<ref name=":4" /> [[NBA]] [[point guard]] [[Kendall Marshall]] tweeted, "PSA: sexual advances without consent is NOT locker room talk."<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4">Alana Horowitz Satlin, [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/pro-athletes-trump-locker-room-talk_us_57fb8fb3e4b0b6a43033cd01 Pro Athletes Say No One Talks Like Trump in Locker Rooms], HuffPost (October 10, 2016).</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/11/us/politics/from-locker-room-talk-to-muslims-report-stuff-the-internet-strikes-back.html|title=From 'Locker Room Talk' to 'Muslims Report Stuff,' the Internet Strikes Back|last=Hauser|first=Christine|date=October 10, 2016|last2=Bromwich|first2=Jonah Engel|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=October 12, 2016}}</ref> [[LA Galaxy]] midfielder [[Robbie Rogers]] tweeted, "I'm offended as an athlete that @realDonaldTrump keeps using this "locker room talk" as an excuse."<ref name=":5" /> Olympic hurdler and sprinter [[Queen Harrison]] tweeted, "Locker room talk,' 'Boys will be boys,' 'Harmless banter.' These are not valid excuses for behavior. Never have been, never will be."<ref name=":5" /> [[Atlanta Falcons]] [[tight end]] [[Jacob Tamme]] tweeted, "It's not normal. And even if it were normal, it's not right."<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":5" /> These responses also prompted the creation of the hashtag #NotInMyLockerRoom.<ref name=":3" />
Eleven months after the footage was leaked, retired professional boxer [[Floyd Mayweather]] defended Trump's comments stating, "People don't like the truth ... He speak like a real man spoke." He added, "So he talking locker room talk. Locker room talk. 'I'm the man, you know what I'm saying? You know who I am. Yeah, I grabbed her by the p---y. And?'"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2733250-floyd-mayweather-donald-trump-is-a-real-man-for-p-y-grabbing-comments|title=Floyd Mayweather: Donald Trump Is a 'Real Man' for P---y Grabbing Comments|last=Wells|first=Adam|date=September 14, 2017|publisher=Bleacher Report|access-date=September 14, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.si.com/boxing/2017/09/14/floyd-mayweather-donald-trump-access-hollywood-tape-comments|title=Floyd Mayweather Says Trump's 'Grab Them by the P----' Comments Are How a 'Real Man' Talks|last=Chavez|first=Chris|date=September 14, 2017|publisher=Sports Illustrated|access-date=September 14, 2017}}</ref>
===Anti-Trump memes and campaigns===
The backlash from the comments prompted a "Pussy Grabs Back" [[hashtag]] urging women to vote against Trump on [[Election Day (United States)|Election Day]]. Anti-Trump memes featuring cat imagery spread on social media. ''The Guardian'' wrote that an image of a snarling cat became a "rallying cry for female rage against Trump".<ref>Nicole Puglise, [https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/oct/10/donald-trump-pussy-grabs-back-meme-women-twitter 'Pussy grabs back' becomes rallying cry for female rage against Trump], ''The Guardian'' (October 10, 2016).</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/donald-trump-the-apprentice-1201887346/|title='Apprentice' Editor Says Trump Made Lewd Comments About Women Between Takes|first=Ted|last=Johnson|date=October 13, 2016|newspaper=Variety}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/tom-hanks-donald-trump-lewd-sexist-comments-offended-as-a-man-video-a7358246.html |title=Tom Hanks was asked if he was 'offended' by Donald Trump. He didn't hold back |date=October 12, 2016 |work=The Independent}}</ref>
Trump's denial that he ever kissed or groped women without consent led to [[Donald Trump sexual misconduct allegations|more accusations]] by several women that Trump sexually assaulted them.<ref>Avila, Theresa. [http://nymag.com/thecut/2016/10/four-women-allege-donald-trump-touched-them-inappropriately.html "4 Women Allege Donald Trump ...."] ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]''. October 13, 2016. October 13, 2016.</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Helderman|first1=Rosalind S.|title=The growing list of women who have stepped forward to accuse Trump of touching them inappropriately|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/the-growing-list-of-women-who-have-stepped-forward-to-accuse-trump-of-touching-them-inappropriately/2016/10/15/a65ddf1c-92df-11e6-9c85-ac42097b8cc0_story.html|p=The Washington Post |date=October 15, 2016 |accessdate=October 15, 2016}}</ref> Trump's campaign denied the allegations.<ref>Stuart, Tessa (October 12, 2016). [https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/features/timeline-of-trumps-creepiness-while-he-owned-miss-universe-w444634 "Timeline of Donald Trump's Creepiness While He Owned Miss Universe"]. ''Rolling Stone''.</ref>
In response to the recording, Shannon Coulter started a viral campaign called #GrabYourWallet, which urges individuals to [[boycott]] various companies that sell Trump related products.<ref name=Boycott>{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Kate|title=An anti-Trump movement is calling for the boycott of these 32 retailers|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/trump-related-businesses-boycotted-2016-11?international=true&r=US&IR=T |publisher=Business Insider |date=November 15, 2016 |accessdate=February 5, 2017}}</ref> Various companies have since dropped Trump's products in response to the boycott, including [[Shoes.com]], [[Nordstrom]], [[Bergdorf Goodman]], and [[Neiman Marcus]].<ref name=Boycott2>{{cite news|last1=McGrath|first1=Maggie|title=A #GrabYourWallet Effect? Following Nordstrom Drop, Ivanka Trump Line Disappears From Neiman Marcus Website|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/maggiemcgrath/2017/02/03/a-grabyourwallet-effect-following-nordstrom-drop-ivanka-trump-line-disappears-from-neiman-marcus-website/#49108e514baa |work=Forbes |date=February 3, 2017 |accessdate=February 5, 2017}}</ref>
===Alleged other tapes=== On October 9, former staffers of Trump's reality show ''[[The Apprentice (US TV series)|The Apprentice]]'' and journalist [[Geraldo Rivera]] said that they both individually have more damaging tapes of Trump, but did not say if they would be released to the public.<ref>{{cite news |first=Kelsey |last=Sutton |title=Geraldo Rivera: 'I have tapes' of 'embarrassing' statements from Trump |date=October 9, 2016 |publisher=[[Politico]] blogs |url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/on-media/2016/10/geraldo-rivera-i-have-tapes-of-embarrassing-statements-from-trump-229433 |accessdate=October 11, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Hadas|authorlink=Hadas Gold|last=Gold |title=David Brock: I will pay for 'Apprentice' tapes |date=October 9, 2016 |publisher=[[Politico]] blogs |url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/on-media/2016/10/david-brock-i-will-pay-for-apprentice-tapes-229432}}</ref> Rivera later stated that he had searched his files and that he could not find anything relevant to the scandal.<ref>{{cite news |last=Flood |first=Brian |url=http://www.thewrap.com/geraldo-rivera-apologizes-to-donald-trump-doesnt-have-dirt-on-him-after-all/ |title=Geraldo Rivera Apologizes to Donald Trump, Doesn't Have Dirt on Him After All |date=October 12, 2016 |publisher=[[TheWrap]] |accessdate=October 12, 2016}}</ref>
Since the tape's release, Bill Pruitt, a producer of the first two seasons of the television series ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. TV series)|The Apprentice]]'', claims there is recorded behind the scenes footage of Trump saying things that are "far worse". NBC's news division does not have access to the archives of the series. Another ''Apprentice'' producer, [[Chris Nee]], claimed on [[Twitter]] that Trump said "the N-word" in the archived footage.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1=David|title=There's Allegedly "Apprentice" Footage of Donald Trump Saying the N-Word|url=http://fortune.com/2016/10/09/theres-allegedly-apprentice-footage-of-donald-trump-saying-the-n-word/ |work=Fortune |date=October 9, 2016 |accessdate=December 20, 2016}}</ref><ref name=Nword>{{cite news|last1=Howard|first1=Adam|title=Days after Trump's lewd comments were revealed, the controversy rolls on|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/trump-s-lewd-comments-2005-still-drawing-fire-n664221 |publisher=NBC News|date=October 11, 2016 |accessdate=December 20, 2016}}</ref> Nee later deleted the tweet.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jane|first1=Talia|title=Tom Arnold says he has 'Apprentice' tapes of Trump saying "n*gger" and "retard"|url=https://mic.com/articles/160460/tom-arnold-says-he-has-apprentice-tapes-of-trump-saying-n-gger-and-retard |publisher=Mic |date=December 20, 2016 |accessdate=December 20, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Mcafee|first1=Tierney|title=Tom Arnold Claims He Has Apprentice Outtakes of Trump Saying the N-Word, the C-Word and Calling His Son a 'Retard'|url=http://people.com/politics/tom-arnold-apprentice-outtakes-trump-n-word-c-word-retard/ |publisher=People |date=December 20, 2016 |accessdate=December 20, 2016}}</ref> A [[GoFundMe]] campaign was launched on October 9 with the goal of raising $5.1 million to release more tapes. The campaign is known as the "Trump Sunlight Campaign". Nee wrote on Twitter to [[Mark Cuban]] that there is a $5 million penalty fee if the footage is leaked.<ref name=Nword/><ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/trump-gofundme-campaign-tapes_us_57fb8ccbe4b0b6a43033c95f There's A GoFundMe To Get Trump's Supposedly Damning 'Apprentice' Tapes Released]</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Mettler|first1=Katie|title='I am NOT pro-Trump,' clarifies 'The Apprentice' producer Mark Burnett amid video controversy|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2016/10/13/i-am-not-pro-trump-clarifies-the-apprentice-producer-mark-burnett-amid-video-controversy/ |work=The Washington Post |date=October 13, 2016 |accessdate=December 20, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Brook|first1=Harold|title=Trump Tapes: The Legal Hurdles To Leaking 'Apprentice' Footage|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/legalentertainment/2016/10/13/trump-tapes-the-laws-behind-leaking-more-footage/#440964d01371 |work=Forbes |date=October 13, 2016 |accessdate=December 20, 2016}}</ref><ref>[http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/trump-s-lewd-comments-2005-still-drawing-fire-n664221 Trump's Lewd Comments From 2005 Still Drawing Fire]</ref><ref>Edelman, Adam (Sunday, October 9, 2016, 7:11 PM). [http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/apprentice-producers-footage-trump-n-word-report-article-1.2824047 Producers of 'The Apprentice' sitting on footage of Donald Trump using N-word: claim]. ''New York Daily News''. Retrieved October 31, 2016.</ref> A few days later, the campaign managed to raise just over $32,000.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Annear|first1=Steve|title=Are there more damaging Trump tapes out there? Somerville man hopes so - The Boston Globe|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2016/10/12/are-there-more-damaging-trump-tapes-out-there-somerville-man-hopes/9jNovnjBO4UFboYg3nAGSI/story.html |work=The Boston Globe |date=October 12, 2016 |accessdate=December 20, 2016}}</ref> [[David Brock]] said he would pay the penalty to release tapes from ''The Apprentice''.<ref>[http://www.newsmax.com/Politics/david-brock-offers-five-million/2016/10/09/id/752471/ David Brock: I'll Cover $5 Million Penalty For Trump 'Apprentice' Tapes]. Retrieved November 1, 2016.</ref><ref>[https://newrepublic.com/article/137742/stop-salivating-trump-tapes Stop Salivating Over More Trump Tapes]. Retrieved November 1, 2016.</ref>
=== Use as a criminal defense === In October 2018, a Florida man was arrested and charged with abusive sexual contact, after [[groping]] a woman aboard a [[Southwest Airlines]] flight. The woman told police when the plane landed that the accused had attempted to touch her breasts twice during the trip.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/flights/2018/10/23/accused-groping-southwest-flight-trump-women-private-parts/1736728002/|title=Man accused of groping woman on flight: Trump 'says it's OK to grab' women's private parts|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2018-10-23|language=en}}</ref> When questioned by police he referenced a quote ["Grab them by the pussy"] from the tape, and that the President of the United States says it's okay to grab women by their private parts.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2018/10/23/alleged-in-flight-groper-trump-says-its-ok-to-grab-womens-private-parts/|title=Alleged in-flight groper: Trump says it‚Äôs ‚Äòok‚Äô to grab women‚Äôs private parts|date=2018-10-23|work=New York Post|access-date=2018-10-23|language=en-US}}</ref>

'''E!''' (originally an [[initialism]] of '''Entertainment Television''') is an American [[Cable television in the United States#Basic cable|basic cable]] and [[satellite television]] [[cable channel|channel]] that is owned by the [[NBCUniversal Cable Entertainment Group]] division of [[NBCUniversal]], all owned by [[Comcast]].
As of January 2016, E! is available to 92.4 million households in America.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/content/cable-network-coverage-area-household-universe-estimates-january-2016/153590 |title=Cable Network Coverage Area Household Universe Estimates: January 2016}}</ref>
== History ==
===Movietime=== E! was originally launched on July 31, 1987, as '''Movietime''', a service that aired movie trailers, entertainment news, event and awards coverage, and interviews as an early example of a national [[barker channel]].<ref>{{cite news|url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CE4DD173CF930A35755C0A966958260&sec=&spon=|work=The New York Times|first= Jeremy|last=Gerard|title=TELEVISION; Fledgling Cable Networks Are Poised for Flight|date=June 3, 1990}}</ref> The channel was founded by [[Larry Namer]] and [[Alan Mruvka]].<ref name="BOOK1">{{cite book|last=Slide|first=Anthony|title=The television industry: a historical dictionary|publisher=[[Greenwood Press]] |year=1991 |edition=illustrated|page=94|isbn=9780313256349|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z4EYAAAAIAAJ&q=alan-mruvka&dq=alan-mruvka}}</ref><ref name="NYT1">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/30/business/advertising-promoting-movies-via-cable.html|title=Advertising; Promoting Movies Via Cable|last=Dougherty |first=Philip H.|date=July 30, 1987|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=June 24, 2009}}</ref> Early Movietime hosts included [[Greg Kinnear]], [[Paula Abdul]], [[Katie Wagner]], [[Julie Moran]], Suzanne Kay (daughter of [[Diahann Carroll]]), [[Mark DeCarlo]], [[Sam Rubin]] and [[Richard Blade]].
===E!=== [[File:E! Logo.svg|thumb|left|75px|E!'s logo from the launch under that branding. Used from June 1, 1990 until July 9, 2012 for the US flagship channel. Still in use for many of E!'s international networks.]] Controlling ownership was originally held by a [[consortium]] of five cable television providers ([[Comcast]], [[Continental Cablevision]], [[Cox Communications|Cox Cable]], [[Tele-Communications Inc.|TCI]], and [[Warner Cable]]), [[HBO]]/[[Warner Communications]], and various founding shareholders, with HBO directly programming and managing the network. In 1989, after [[Time-Life]] bought Warner Communications to fend off a takeover bid by Paramount, the new [[Time Warner]] company held four of the eight major ownership positions and took over management control of Movietime and renamed the network as '''E!: Entertainment Television''' on June 1, 1990; this name change was made to emphasize its widening coverage of the [[celebrity‚Äìindustrial complex]], contemporary film, television and music, daily Hollywood gossip, and fashion.
In 1997, Comcast, one of the minority partners, teamed up with [[Disney‚ÄìABC Television Group|Disney/ABC Cable Networks]] to buy the channel after Time-Warner had exercised their put agreement.<ref>[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-19020738.html Comcast Corp. Gains Exclusive Right to Buy E! Entertainment], Knight Ridder/Tribune Business News (originated from ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]''; via [[HighBeam Research]]), January 11, 1997.</ref> Comcast increased the ownership stakes in the network through mergers with forerunners of TCI and Continental under various circumstances. In November 2006, Comcast acquired Disney's 39.5% share of E! for $1.23 billion to gain full ownership of the network as part of a broader programming carriage agreement between Disney/ABC and Comcast.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.comcast.com/About/PressRelease/PressReleaseDetail.ashx?PRID=24|title= Comcast and the Walt Disney Company Announce Long-Term Comprehensive Distribution Agreements Securing Carriage for Disney Media Networks‚Äô Products and Services|publisher=[[Comcast]]|accessdate=March 19, 2012}}</ref>
In January 2011, Comcast Entertainment Group, the company's television unit, became a division of the [[NBCUniversal Television Group]], after Comcast acquired a 51% majority stake in NBCUniversal from [[General Electric]].<ref>[http://www.pcworld.com/article/183652/nbcuniversalcomcast_merger_what_we_do_and_dont_know.html NBC-Universal-Comcast Merger: What We Do and Don't Know], ''[[PC World (magazine)|PCWorld]]'', December 3, 2009.</ref> E!'s only sister networks prior to the NBC Universal merger were the now-defunct channels Style Network (then [[Esquire Network]]) and [[G4 (U.S. TV channel)|G4]], along with Comcast's sports networks: Versus, [[Comcast SportsNet]] and [[Golf Channel]]. In the case of Versus, E! staff produced that network's ''[[Sports Soup]]'' and G4's ''[[Web Soup]]'', while the Orlando-based Golf Channel featured no crossovers with E! at all due to incompatible audiences and operations. Versus and Golf Channel were taken under the direct control of the [[NBC Sports]] division, with the former being renamed [[NBC Sports Network]] in January 2012, and are no longer connected to their former sister networks beyond advertising and in-house operations.
On July 9, 2012, the channel introduced a revised logo (the first change to its logo since the network rebranded as E! in 1990), removing the [[exclamation mark]] background behind the "E" but keeping the exclamation point underneath, along with a new slogan "Pop of Culture", which coincided with the launch of the new series ''[[Opening Act]]''. The network also started the process of introducing scripted programming (the first series, ''[[The Royals (TV series)|The Royals]]'', premiering in March 2015), in addition to its existing reality and documentary series. The changes were announced during E!'s programming upfront presentation on April 30, 2012.<ref>[http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/e-new-logo-pop-of-culture-tagline-318032 E! Unveils New Logo, 'Pop of Culture' Tagline], ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', April 30, 2012.</ref>
==Programming== {{main|List of programs broadcast by E!}}
===News=== {{see also|E! News}} E! is one of the few U.S. general-entertainment cable channels that broadcasts a daily news program; its flagship entertainment news program is ''[[E! News]]'', which debuted on September 1, 1991. The weekday program (which also has an hour-long weekend edition) features stories and gossip about celebrities, and the film, music and television industries, and has been broadcast under various formats since its launch, even being aired live for a time during the mid-2000s. It was first hosted by Dagny Hultgreen. Steve Kmetko was a host from 1994-2002.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} It has been hosted by [[Terrence Jenkins]] and [[Giuliana Rancic]] since 2012 and 2006, respectively, with [[Ryan Seacrest]] (who co-anchored the program from 2006 to 2012) serving as [[managing editor]] of the news operation.
''E! News'' was the only entertainment news show on the channel for much of its history until 2006, when the channel launched ''[[The Daily 10]]'', hosted by [[Sal Masekela]] and [[Catt Sadler]] ([[Debbie Matenopoulos]] also co-hosted from the show's inception until 2008); the series was cancelled in September 2010 after E! announced that the weekday editions of ''E! News'' would be expanded to one hour starting on October 25, 2010.<ref>[http://www.multichannel.com/article/457412-E_Expands_Weeknight_Newscast_To_One_Hour.php E! Expands Weeknight Newscast To One Hour] 2011 NewBay Media September 21, 2010</ref>
E! also carried a [[simulcast]] of business news channel [[Bloomberg Television]] from 2004 to January 2009, when the latter network had expanded its cable and satellite carriage to a level that allowed the discontinuation of the simulcast. During its time on E!, the 5 to 8 a.m. block was the most watched period for the network, according to [[Nielsen Media Research]].{{citation needed|date=October 2013}}
Outside ''E! News'' telecasts, the channel runs an ''E! News''‚Äìbranded ticker displaying entertainment news headlines each half-hour during regular programming (except during airings of ''E! News'' and ''The Soup'', and the channel's early morning infomercial block) which is updated daily; fast-breaking entertainment headlines (such as a celebrity arrest or death) may also be displayed on a ticker, during any program when warranted.
===Original series=== E! is known for its live red carpet pre-shows for the industry's three prominent award shows, the [[Primetime Emmy Award]]s, the [[Golden Globe Award]]s, and the [[Academy Awards]], and were famous for their fashion critiques by [[Joan Rivers]]; Rivers also hosted post-awards specials under the title ''[[Fashion Police]]'', which became a regular weekly series in September 2010. In April 2017, it was announced that E! had acquired the [[People's Choice Awards]], which will move to the network from [[CBS]] in 2018 with a new November scheduling. The network promoted that the show would be given an "end-to-end" experience that will leverage its existing experience in awards show coverage.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2017/12/peoples-choice-awards-premiere-date-e-den-of-thieves-jesse-ignjatovic-evan-prager-1202226809/|title=People‚Äôs Choice Awards Sets Premiere Date For Inaugural Telecast On E!|last=Ramos|first=Dino-Ray|date=2017-12-14|work=Deadline|access-date=2017-12-14|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2017/04/peoples-choice-awards-cbs-e-1202063827/|title=People‚Äôs Choice Awards Moves From CBS To E!|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|date=2017-04-06|work=Deadline|access-date=2017-12-14|language=en-US}}</ref>
The network also produces many documentary and biographical series, most notably ''[[E! True Hollywood Story]]''; many of E!'s original specials are entertainment-related ranging from light fare (such as ''25 Cutest Child Stars All Grown Up'') to serious fare (such as ''15 Most Unforgettable Hollywood Tragedies''). It also produces specials centering on investigative and crime stories including ''E! Investigates'', which features topical investigative reports on subjects ranging from [[child prostitution]] to [[teenage pregnancy]].
In recent years, the network has become known for its [[reality television]] programs. Its most popular series as of 2011 is ''[[Keeping Up with the Kardashians]]'', which has spawned three [[Spin-off (media)|spin-offs]] (''[[Kourtney and Khlo√© Take Miami]]'', ''[[Kourtney and Kim Take New York]]'', and ''[[Khloe and Lamar]]''). Other original programming airing on the network included weekly version of ''[[Fashion Police (TV series)|Fashion Police]]'' (which continues as post-awards ceremony specials).
E! has had three comedy programs: the late night talk show ''[[Chelsea Lately]]'', hosted by comedian [[Chelsea Handler]], its scripted/improvised spin-off ''[[After Lately]]'', and ''[[The Soup]]'' (based on the popular 1991-2002 E! series ''[[Talk Soup]]''), featuring clips of the previous week's TV shows with humorous commentary delivered by the host, actor/comedian [[Joel McHale]]. Handler also produced ''[[Love You, Mean It with Whitney Cummings|Love You, Mean It]]'', a weekly comedic look at pop culture hosted by [[Whitney Cummings]].
===Acquired series and films=== Over the years, E! has occasionally run acquired programming including reruns of ''[[Alice (TV series)|Alice]]'', ''[[Absolutely Fabulous]]'', ''[[20/20 (U.S. TV series)|20/20]]'' lifestyle-based interview shows from [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] (since removed under NBCUniversal ownership), and edited 60-minute versions of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', though fewer of these programs currently air.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url= http://www.marketingmag.ca/news/media-news/out-with-the-e-in-with-the-new-at-canwest-upfront-8989|title=Out with the E!, in with the new at Canwest upfront|work=[[Marketing (magazine)|Marketing Magazine]]|date=June 3, 2009|accessdate=August 19, 2011}}</ref> The only programming currently airing on E! that it does not produce are [[standards and practices|broadcast standards-edited]] reruns of the former [[HBO]] series ''[[Sex and the City]]'' originally carried by HBO's sister network [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]], and [[feature film]]s that air under the banner "Movies We Love"; the latter was part of a since-abandoned initiative by the network to use films to increase the network's ratings, though the branding remains, and low and mid-grossing female focused films from the [[Universal Pictures]] library usually receive their basic cable premiere on E!, with higher-grossing films premiering on [[USA Network]]. The network has aired same-week runs of NBC series (such as ''[[The Voice (U.S.)|The Voice]]'', ''[[Fashion Star]]'', ''[[Whitney (TV series)|Whitney]]'', and ''[[Are You There, Chelsea?]]''), and in the past aired previews of G4 programming to give that network an extended promotional platform due to their lowered carriage when it was removed from [[DirecTV]] in November 2010.<ref name="auto"/>
==E! HD== '''E! HD''' is a [[High-definition television|high definition]] simulcast feed of E! that launched on December 8, 2008; like the rest of E!'s sister lifestyle and sports networks owned by former parent [[Comcast Entertainment Group]] and subsequently the NBC cable networks, the feed broadcasts in the [[1080i]] resolution format. Currently, filmed program content and all of the network's post-2010 programs, along with limited pre-2010 content is carried in the format, with HD programming airing in a [[letterbox]] format on the SD channel (some films remain in [[480i]] due to contractual or technical reasons). The HD feed is available on most cable and telco providers, along with both satellite services.<ref name="auto"/>
During E!'s run as a broadcast service in Canada, the ''E! Ontario'' version of the service until the December 2008 discontinuation of the E! broadcast television system was available in HD over [[Hamilton, Ontario]]-based [[CHCH-TV]] (channel 11) on its channel 18 digital signal, though the majority of E!'s programming outside American primetime series before the shutdown of the [[television system]] was not available in the format.<ref name="auto"/>
==''E! Online''== ''E! Online'' is the online arm of E!, featuring live updates on entertainment news stories; the website includes an online-only entertainment news bulletin titled ''E! News Now'', which is updated each weekday. The website also provides live streaming video of major red carpet events including movie premieres and award shows such as the Academy Awards and the Emmys, along with some blogs involving shows such as ''The Soup''. Columnists featured on the website include [[Kristin dos Santos]] (the "Watch with Kristin" television blog), [[Ted Casablanca]] ("The Awful Truth" gossip blog), and Marc Malkin (writer of an eponymous gossip blog and host of a daily video blog on the site).{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}
As part of the rebrand of the cable channel on July 9, 2012, EOnline.com was redesigned for [[HTML5]], including tablet and mobile devices.<ref>[http://www.lostremote.com/2012/05/01/e-emphasizes-social-presence-and-tablet-friendliness-at-upfront/ E! emphasizes social presence and tablet friendliness at upfront], ''The Lost Remote'', May 1, 2012. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504054452/http://www.lostremote.com/2012/05/01/e-emphasizes-social-presence-and-tablet-friendliness-at-upfront/ |date=May 4, 2012 }}</ref>

===Canada=== Unlike most international cable channels that have licensed an American cable channel's branding and programming, E! has existed as two separate television channels in Canada ‚Äì in both broadcast and pay television forms.<ref name="auto"/>
On September 7, 2007, [[Canwest|Canwest Global Communications]] rebranded its CH television system as [[E! (Canadian TV system)|E!]] CH originally launched on February 12, 2001 by [[CHCH-DT|CHCH]]/[[Hamilton, Ontario]] as a secondary service of the [[Global Television Network]]; the CH/E! system would later include four additional Canwest-owned stations in [[Quebec]] ([[CJNT-DT|CJNT]]/[[Montreal]]), [[British Columbia]] ([[CHEK-DT|CHEK]]/[[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]] and [[CHBC-TV|CHBC]]/[[Kelowna]]) and [[Alberta]] ([[CHCA-TV|CHCA]]/[[Red Deer, Alberta|Red Deer]]), and three affiliates owned by [[Jim Pattison Group]] in British Columbia ([[CKPG-TV|CKPG]]/[[Prince George, British Columbia|Prince George]] and [[CFJC-TV|CFJC]]/[[Kamloops, British Columbia|Kamloops]]) and Alberta ([[CHAT-TV|CHAT]]/[[Medicine Hat, Alberta|Medicine Hat]]). The E! television system shut down on September 1, 2009 due to low ratings and corporate financial difficulties that eventually led to Canwest filing for [[bankruptcy protection]] and selling its properties to [[Shaw Media]] for $6.7 million USD; the E! [[owned-and-operated station]]s experienced varied fates (CHCH and CJNT were sold to [[Channel Zero (company)|Channel Zero]], CHEK was sold to an employee-led group; CHBC remained with Canwest and was converted into a Global O&O, and CHCA ceased operations outright), while the Pattison Group stations affiliated with the [[Rogers Media]]-owned [[Citytv]] system.<ref name="auto"/> As E!, local news and other regional programming, as well as most local community sponsorships on the O&O stations, used local branding (incorporating the callsign branding scheme common with Canadian stations not owned by a network or television system).<ref name="auto"/> This decision was at least partly made to avoid confusion with ''E! News'', but likely intended to ensure that local newscasts were not perceived as celebrity-oriented.<ref name="auto"/>
The E! brand would later return to Canada on November 1, 2010, when [[CTVglobemedia]] (whose assets are now owned by [[Bell Media]]) signed a multi-year/multi-platform agreement with Comcast to rebrand [[Category A services|Category 2]] [[specialty channel]] Star! (which had a similar format to E! U.S. and had carried some of its programming prior to the 2007 rebranding of CH) into a [[E! (Canadian TV channel)|Canadian version of E!]] on November 29, 2010.

'''Fictional portrayals of psychopaths''', or '''sociopaths''', are some of the most notorious in film and literature but may only vaguely or partly relate to the concept of [[psychopathy]], which is itself used with varying definitions by [[mental health professional]]s, [[criminologist]]s and others. The character may be identified as a diagnosed/assessed psychopath or sociopath within the fictional work itself, or by its creator when discussing their intentions with the work, which might be distinguished from opinions of audiences or [[critic]]s based only on a character appearing to show traits or behaviors associated with an undefined popular stereotype of psychopathy.
Such characters are often portrayed in an [[exaggeration|exaggerated]] fashion and typically in the role of a [[villain]] or [[antihero]], where the general characteristics of a psychopath are useful to facilitate conflict and danger. Because the definitions and criteria in the [[history of psychopathy]] have varied over the years and continue to change even now, many characters in notable films may have been designed to fall under the category of a psychopath at the time of the film's production or release, but not necessarily in subsequent years. There are several [[stereotypical]] images of psychopathy in both [[Layperson|lay]] and professional accounts which only partly overlap and can involve contradictory traits: the charming [[con artist]], the deranged [[serial killer]], the successful [[Psychopathy in the workplace|corporate psychopath]], or the chronic low-level [[crime|offender]] with [[juvenile delinquency]]. The public concept reflects some combination of fear of the mythical [[bogeyman]], fascination with human [[evil]], and sometimes perhaps [[envy]] of people who might appear to go through life unencumbered by the same levels of [[Guilt (emotion)|guilt]], [[anguish]] or [[Emotional security|insecurity]].<ref name="gap">{{cite journal |last=Skeem|first=J. L.|author2=Polaschek, D. L. L.|author3=Patrick, C. J.|author4=Lilienfeld, S. O.|title=Psychopathic Personality: Bridging the Gap Between Scientific Evidence and Public Policy|journal=Psychological Science in the Public Interest|date=15 December 2011|volume=12|issue=3|pages=95‚Äì162|doi=10.1177/1529100611426706|url=http://www.psychologicalscience.org/index.php/publications/journals/pspi/psychopathy.html}}</ref>
==Early depictions== In the 19th century the diagnostic categories of [[monomania]] or [[moral insanity]] (the word 'moral' then meant either emotional or ethical) made their way into works of literature, covering numerous eccentricities, obsessions or breakdowns‚Äîand sometimes acts of apparently senseless criminality, occasionally violent. This period also saw the rise of [[crime fiction]] such as [[sensation novels]], where often someone in a local community who appeared normal would turn out to be criminally insane, and [[detective novels]], playing on increasing anxieties about the characters of people in the newly expanding and diversifying industrial cities.<ref name=Thesing>{{cite book |title=A companion to the Victorian novel |author=Patrick Brantlinger, William B. Thesing |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PMWWh6yu3oEC |page=76 & 236|isbn= 0-631-22064-X |year=2002 |publisher=Wiley-Blackwell}}</ref> The term 'psychopath' came into use in the late 19th century (as did the term it would often be confused with, [[psychotic]]), and also spanned a very wide range of conditions ([[etymologically]] and originally equivalent to 'mentally ill'). Nevertheless, an early rise to prominence followed its use in a Russian trial between 1883 and 1885 concerning a child murder, contributing to the release of a probable false confessor while the original suspect was found guilty. 'Psychopaths' began to appear in [[vaudeville]]s, ditties (songs) and press articles. The psychopathy defense was reported internationally as having enabled a remorseless female child killer to go free, a usage still quoted in dictionaries today.<ref>[[Oxford English Dictionary]] 2011: Psychopath: 1885 Pall Mall G. 21 Jan. Article archive text via [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F50E17F7345F15738DDDAD0994DA405B8584F0D3 MLLE. SEMENOVA'S ACQUITTAL] 1885 NY Times from Pall Mall Gazette. [http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=psychopath&allowed_in_frame=0 Online Etymology Dictionary: Psychopath] cites instead a reference to the british Daily Telegraph's coverage of the case. Retrieved August 26th 2013</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=63GLlNV2xFQC Murder Most Russian: True Crime and Punishment in Late Imperial Russia] Louise McReynolds, Cornell University Press, 18 Dec 2012 (spells child victim as Sarra Bekker).</ref>
[[Degeneration|'Degenerates']] were also depicted in popular fiction of the 19th through to mid 20th century, sometimes in similar ways to the modern usages of the concept of psychopaths, sometimes being cited as a cause of psychopathy. The concept fell into disrepute due partly to its use by the Nazis to justify eradicating their opposition.<ref name=Jalava>[http://summit.sfu.ca/item/8120 Science of conscience: Metaphysics, morality, and rhetoric in psychopathy research] Jarkko Jalava, 2007, PhD at Simon Fraser University, then Professor at Okanagan College, Canada</ref>
==Early 20th century== The meaning gradually narrowed, initially as 'psychopathic inferiors' covering all of what today might be called [[personality disorders]] and various other conditions, then intertwining with the terminology of the 'sociopath' (and eventually [[antisocial personality disorder]]), though psychopathy remained variously defined in both broad and narrow ways.
Early representations of psychopaths in film were often caricatured as sadistic, unpredictable, sexually depraved, and emotionally unstable ([[mania|manic]]) characters with a compulsion to engage in random violence and destruction, usually with a series of bizarre mannerisms such as giggling, laughing, or facial [[tics]]. Up until the late 1950s, cinematic conventions usually relegated the psychopath to roles of genre villains such as gangsters, [[mad scientists]], [[supervillains]], and many types of generic criminals. Examples of this type are [[Pinkie Brown]] ([[Richard Attenborough]]) in ''[[Brighton Rock (1947 film)|Brighton Rock]]'', Tommy Udo ([[Richard Widmark]]) in ''[[Kiss of Death (1947 film)|Kiss of Death]]'', Cody Jarrett ([[James Cagney]]) in ''[[White Heat (film)|White Heat]]'', and [[Tony Camonte|Antonio 'Tony' Camonte]] ([[Paul Muni]]) in the 1932 version of ''[[Scarface (1932 film)|Scarface]]''. [[Homosexuals]] were also referred to as psychopaths under the broad definition then in use; the [[American Psychiatric Association]] in the first [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]] in 1952 would list it under 'sociopathic personality disturbance'.
One exceptional depiction in this period was the character of child murderer Hans Beckert ([[Peter Lorre]]) in the 1931 [[Fritz Lang]] film ''[[M (1931 film)|M]]''. Lorre portrays Beckert as an outwardly unremarkable man tormented by a compulsion to ritualistically murder children. A German film (allegedly based on the real life [[serial killer]] [[Peter K√ºrten]]), it was released in America in 1933 and has been seen as indicative of a turning point in American media depictions of psychopaths. Until the 1930s psychiatrists typically applied the diagnosis to unemployed males or 'hypersexual' women, but several psychiatric, cultural and economic trends, together with [[sex crime]] panics, converged to transform the popular psychopath into a violent, male, sexual deviant or criminal‚Äîa threat to innocence, [[gender role]]s and the [[social order]].<ref>[https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/1908506?uid=3738032&uid=2129&uid=2&uid=70&uid=4&sid=21102561687811 "Uncontrolled Desires": The Response to the Sexual Psychopath, 1920-1960] Estelle B. Freedman, The Journal of American History, Vol. 74, No. 1 (Jun., 1987), pp. 83-106. Also reproduced in [https://books.google.com/books?id=5jTjfFo42E8C Passion and Power: Sexuality in History (from Pg 199)]</ref>
The [[Ostap Bender]] character from novels [[The Twelve Chairs]] and [[The Little Golden Calf]] by Soviet authors [[Ilf and Petrov]] is also considered a portrait of a charming psychopath.<ref>[https://www.b17.ru/blog/11662/ Be cautious - socially adapted psychopath, damned attractive man]</ref><ref>[http://tanja-tank.livejournal.com/34480.html sociopaths and narcissists in movies]</ref>
Lennie Small from [[Of Mice and Men]], who is mentally retarded, has been described as also lacking a conscience or moral sense, a common definition of a [[psychopath]].<ref>https://www.cliffsnotes.com/literature/o/of-mice-and-men/character-analysis/lennie-small</ref> His inability to stay out of trouble is often attributed to this.
==Mid 20th century== One of the earliest real life cases which had a pervasive influence on American movies was that of [[Ed Gein]], arrested in 1957. A farmer who had resided with his mother until her death, he had then killed two women and dug up female bodies from the local [[cemetery]], making various items out of their skin. Rumours spread that he was also a [[necrophiliac]], [[cannibal]] or [[transvestite]], though these appear to have been unsupported other than by brief affirmations from Gein to [[leading questions]] by interrogators.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Z_ZDUR7H_QMC&source=gbs_navlinks_s Deviant] Harold Schechter, 1998, Pg 192, 238</ref><ref>[http://www.robertcdaniels.com/ed_gein.htm#_ftn2 Ed Gein: the Cannibal Myth Exposed]</ref> Gein was found mentally ill and legally insane before trial, deemed to have had [[schizophrenia]] (psychosis including [[delusions]] and [[hallucinations]]) for at least 12 years, though at least one media psychiatrist dubbed him instead a 'sexual psychopath'.<ref>Gonyea, Floyd. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=XG1QAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dBAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4721,3004948&dq=gein&hl=en "Ed Gein Adjudged Insane"] ''Milwaukee Sentinel''. January 7, 1958.</ref><ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iJJHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=r3wMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4710,515516&dq=gein&hl=en "Rule Woman Butcher Edward Gein insane; Sent to State Hospital"] ''Warsaw Times-Union''. January 7, 1958.</ref> [[Robert Bloch]], a prolific pulp horror author, says his 1959 novel ''[[Psycho (novel)|Psycho]]'' was based on the Gein murders and the idea of an apparently sane person in a local community committing heinous crimes, but not necessarily on Gein himself, despite numerous similarities.<ref>[http://mediageeknetwork.com/psycho-exclusive-an-interview-with-author-robert-bloch/ PSYCHO EXCLUSIVE: An Interview With Author Robert Bloch] By Ed Gross, Media Geek Network, November 24, 2012</ref> The villain, [[Norman Bates]], is portrayed as an outwardly unremarkable man who murders a woman while under the control of an [[disassociative identity disorder|alternate personality]] that takes the form of [[Norma Bates (Psycho)|his domineering mother]], who he himself murdered. Both the novel and [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s [[Psycho (1960 film)|1960 film adaptation]] were influences on the popular media portrayal of psychopaths.<ref>[http://www.penguin-readers.com/pdf/downloads/pr/teachers-notes/9781405879286.pdf Teacher's Notes: Psycho] Penguin 2008</ref><ref name=Sullivan>[http://www.ejumpcut.org/archive/onlinessays/JC43folder/EdGein.html Ed Gein and the figure of the transgendered serial killer] by K.E. Sullivan. from Jump Cut: A Review of Contemporary Media, no. 43, July 2000, pp. 38-47</ref> Neither the book nor film elaborates on the term 'psycho', though it is commonly taken to refer to either psychotic or psychopath. At the end of the film, a psychiatrist describes Bates as having a split personality. [[Multiple personality disorder]] was at that time very popular (cf 1957 movie ''[[The Three Faces of Eve]]'') and is to this day commonly confused with [[schizophrenia]]. Bloch later wrote a script for the 1966 film ''[[The Psychopath]]'', the original working title for which was "Schizo".<ref>[http://www.britmovie.co.uk/films/The-Psychopath_1966 The Psychopath ‚Äì 1966: Plot Synopsis]</ref>
A different thread within fictional portrayals of psychopathy continued to focus on rebelliously antisocial characters. The title of the 1955 film ''[[Rebel Without a Cause]]'', starring [[James Dean]], came from a 1944 book of the same name detailing the [[hypnosis|hypno]]-[[Psychoanalysis|analysis]] of a diagnosed psychopath. In the book, psychiatrist [[Robert M. Lindner]] also discussed psychopaths in general as pointlessly selfish individuals who appear unable to accept society's rules. In [[Ken Kesey]]'s 1962 novel ''[[One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (novel)|One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest]]'', [[Randle McMurphy]], after being admitted to a mental institution, is repeatedly referred to by the authorities, other patients and himself as a possible or definite psychopath. He reads from his record: "repeated outbreaks of passion that suggest the possible diagnosis of psychopath", and adds that a doctor told him it means "I fight and fuh-pardon me, ladies-means I am he put it overzealous in my sexual relations." The current doctor then reads out the note: "Don't overlook the possibility that this man might be feigning psychosis".<ref>http://www.shmoop.com/one-flew-over-cuckoos-nest/madness-quotes.html</ref> In the script for the popular [[One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (film)|film adaptation]] in 1975, only the latter is retained and the term psychopath is never used. Ironically, the main authority figure in the hospital‚Äîthe cold, [[sadistic personality disorder|sadistic]] [[Nurse Ratched]]‚Äîwas later described as a psychopath under later understandings of the term.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=LBIjsk-2ok4C The Psychopath in Film] 1999 By Wayne Wilson. Pg 68</ref>
==Late 20th century== The 1973 film ''[[Badlands (film)|Badlands]]'' involved two lead characters based loosely on [[Charles Starkweather]] and [[Caril Ann Fugate]]. While the male lead Kit ([[Martin Sheen]]) is sometimes described as a psychopath or sociopath, psychologist [[Robert D. Hare]], a leading proponent of the assessment of psychopathy, has identified Holly ([[Sissy Spacek]]) as exemplifying his concept of a psychopath due to her poor emotional sense of the meaning of events and her attempted mask of normality. However, writer and director [[Terrence Malick]] has said he considered Kit's shallow, bitter insensitivity to be a result of suffering and neglect growing up in the [[Midwestern United States|Midwest]], and 15-year-old Holly, though immature and mis-estimating her audience, to be a quite typical [[Southern United States|Southern]] girl wanting to help narrate and come off well but still give the hard facts, and not dwell on herself or on personal tragedies.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=xfIEVtzj52YC Without Conscience: The Disturbing World of the Psychopaths Among Us] Robert D. Hare, Guilford Press, 1993/2011. Pg 85</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=jSNCB6yCJPoC Terrence Malick] Lloyd Michaels, University of Illinois Press, 2009. Pg 103</ref>
The increasing media focus of serial killers in the late 20th century, fueled by cases such as [[John Wayne Gacy]] (1978), [[Ted Bundy]] (1978) and [[Jeffrey Dahmer]] (1991), lent an additional momentum to the way psychopathy was both perceived and portrayed in film and literature, sometimes incorporating a hybrid of traditional psychopaths from early film and late-19th century literature with the high-functioning behaviors detected in some serial killers.<ref>[https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc3228/m2/1/high_res_d/thesis.pdf Serial Killing Myths Versus Reality: A Content Analysis of Serial Killer Movies Made Between 1980 and 2001] Sarah Scott McCready, Masters Thesis, 2002</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1111/j.1542-734X.1995.1801_87.x | volume=18 | issue=1 | title=Consuming Cannibals: Psychopathic Killers as Archetypes and Cultural Icons | year=1995 | journal=The Journal of American Culture | pages=87‚Äì96 | last1 = Grixti | first1 = Joseph}}</ref>
The psychiatrist and [[cannibalism|cannibalistic]] serial killer [[Dr. Hannibal Lecter]], most notably portrayed by [[Anthony Hopkins]] in the [[Academy Award]]-winning 1991 film ''[[The Silence of the Lambs (film)|The Silence of the Lambs]]'', is perhaps the most infamous fictional psychopath of the 20th century. Lecter is intelligent and sophisticated (whereas psychopathy is generally associated with lower than average verbal [[intelligence]]<ref name="LecterIntelligence">{{cite journal |last=DeLisi|first=Matt|author2=Vaughn, Michael G.|author3=Beaver, Kevin M.|author4=Wright, John Paul|title=The Hannibal Lecter Myth: Psychopathy and Verbal Intelligence in the MacArthur Violence Risk Assessment Study|journal=Journal of Psychopathology and Behavioral Assessment|volume=32|issue=2|pages=169‚Äì177|doi=10.1007/s10862-009-9147-z|url=http://www.soc.iastate.edu/staff/delisi/Hannibal%20Lecter%20PDF.pdf|year=2009}}</ref>), and his disarming charisma and wit disguise his true nature as a serial killer. He spends most of the film in a cell, taunting [[Clarice Starling]] with clues to the identity of another serial killer, [[Buffalo Bill (The Silence of the Lambs)|Buffalo Bill]], in exchange for intimate details of Starling's troubled childhood. Lecter first appeared in [[Thomas Harris]]' 1981 novel ''[[Red Dragon (novel)|Red Dragon]]'', in which he is characterized as not fitting any known psychological profile. In the film adaptation of ''The Silence of the Lambs'', he is referred to as a "pure psychopath".<ref>In ''[[Red Dragon (novel)|Red Dragon]]'' and its first film adaptation, ''[[Manhunter (film)|Manhunter]]'', FBI profiler [[Will Graham (fictional character)|Will Graham]] suggests that psychologists "say he's a sociopath" because they "don't know what else to call him". Shortly afterwards in ''Red Dragon'', Lecter's jailer [[Frederick Chilton]] says "...we thought he might provide us with a singular opportunity to study a pure sociopath...As it turned out, I don't think we're any closer to understanding him now than the day he came in." In the script for the film version of ''The Silence of the Lambs'', the same character calls Lecter a "pure psychopath". In the novel of the same name, FBI agent [[Jack Crawford (character)|Jack Crawford]] tells Starling "I'm waist-deep in inaccessible patient evaluations of Dr. Lecter and they're all different" and Chilton later tells Starling "A pure sociopath, that's obviously what he is. But he's impenetrable, much too sophisticated for the standard tests."</ref> In the later novels ''[[Hannibal (Harris novel)|Hannibal]]'' and ''[[Hannibal Rising]]'', Lecter's psychopathy is portrayed as the result of seeing his sister Mischa murdered and cannibalized during [[World War II]]. In 2013 Harris revealed that he originally based the Lecter character on Alfredo Ball√≠ Trevino, a Mexican physician who had killed and dismembered his [[homosexual]] lover, in what was called a [[crime of passion]] over a financial dispute.<ref>[http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/articles/495908/20130731/hannibal-lecter-gay-mexican-doctor-alfredo-ball.htm Real Hannibal Lecter was Murderous Gay Mexican Doctor Alfredo Ball√≠ Trevi√±o] Umberto Bacchi, IB Times, July 2013</ref><ref>[http://www.latintimes.com/articles/6867/20130730/real-hannibal-lecter-gay-mexican-doctor-alfredo-balli-trevino-inspiration-thomas-harris-silence-lambs-25-anniversary.htm Who Was The Real Hannibal Lecter?] Valdez, Latin Times, 2013</ref>
The novel ''[[American Psycho]]'' tells the story of [[Patrick Bateman]], a [[yuppie]] serial killer working on [[Wall Street]] in the 1980s. It was made into a [[American Psycho (film)|film]] in 2000. Author [[Bret Easton Ellis]] has told interviewers that the book is a satire on shallow [[consumerist]] lifestyles, but also that the writing of the violent scenes was based on fictional horror and FBI material on serial killers, along with how he imagined "a psychotic who worked on Wall Street" would describe such incidents. Some commentary, including in scientific journals, has suggested the Bateman character appears to be a psychopath. However, Bateman also exhibits signs of psychosis such as hallucinations, and as such appears to be an [[unreliable narrator]]; it is left ambiguous whether Bateman is actually a serial killer, or is merely hallucinating about committing murder.<ref>[http://www.theparisreview.org/interviews/6127/the-art-of-fiction-no-216-bret-easton-ellis Bret Easton Ellis, The Art of Fiction] No. 216. Interviewed by Jon-Jon Goulian</ref><ref>[https://sites.google.com/a/slu.edu/pcn-oct12/psychology-fun/fun-facts ‚ÄúPsycho for Psychology: American Psycho‚Äù] Amanda Sebester, October 2012</ref> In Ellis' 1998 novel ''[[Glamorama]]'' which features models-turned-terrorists a character also remarks "basically, everyone was a sociopath...and all the girls' hair was chignoned."
In the 1993 book ''[[Girl, Interrupted]]'' and its 1999 [[Girl, Interrupted (film)|film adaptation]], the character of Lisa (played by [[Angelina Jolie]] in the film) is a rebellious, antisocial young woman who is diagnosed as a sociopath.<ref>[http://college.cengage.com/psychology/resources/students/screen/screen_20000110.html Girl, Interrupted‚ÄîCuckoo's Nest Redux] By Elaine Cassel, 2000</ref> However, it is left ambiguous whether that diagnosis is accurate.
The 1996 film ''[[Primal Fear (film)|Primal Fear]]'' depicts a suspected murderer who appears to suffer from [[multiple personality disorder]], who at the end reveals that he has been faking the disorder. In the original novel by [[William Diehl]], the psychiatrist Molly Arrington and others repeatedly explain psychopathy and psychosis as if they are the same, inherently antisocial, condition.
''[[Harry Potter]]'' author [[J. K. Rowling]] has described [[Lord Voldemort]], the series' main villain, as "a raging psychopath, devoid of the normal human responses to other people's suffering, and there ARE people like that in the world".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accio-quote.org/articles/2000/0900-ew-jensen.htm|author=Jensen, Jeff. |title='Fire' Storm |work=Entertainment Weekly |date=7 September 2000}}</ref>
==21st century== Numerous characters in television shows are informally described as psychopaths by the [[actors]] who play the parts. Examples include [[Natalie Buxton]] in ''[[Bad Girls (TV series)|Bad Girls]]'',<ref>http://www.badgirls.co.uk/library/int-s6-db.html</ref> [[Sean Slater]] and [[Michael Moon (EastEnders)|Michael Moon]] in ''[[EastEnders]]'',<ref>http://www.bettingpress.com/category/Entertainment/Who-killed-Archie-Mitchell-update--Sean-Slater-now-favourite-in-Eastenders-betting-201002160062/</ref><ref>http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a373916/eastenders-michael-moon-is-a-psychopath-says-steve-john-shepherd.html</ref> and [[Dexter Morgan]] in the American show ''[[Dexter (TV series)|Dexter]].''<ref>http://darklydexter.com/articles/michael-c-hall-and-kevin-dutton-discuss-about-psychopathy/</ref> <ref>https://www.rollingstone.com/tv/features/jodie-comer-meet-killing-eves-pink-dressed-psychopathic-breakout-star-w520872</ref>
[[David Platt (Coronation Street)|David Platt]] from the British TV soap ''[[Coronation Street]]'', is also known for having a serious personality disorder. His character is famous for presenting several tendencies of a sociopathic personality including, manipulation, lying, and aggression. He has served time in prison and often blames his mother for his traumatic childhood, His character has matured over the years however, the mask tends to slip from time to time and he returns to his darker side, most recently when he helped hide a dead body with a terrifying, cold-hearted attitude.
[[Gregory House|Dr. Gregory House]], the title character in the FOX medical-thriller ''[[House (TV series)|House]]'' is referred to as a sociopath multiple times by several characters throughout the course of the show.
[[Sherlock Holmes]], the lead character in the BBC series ''[[Sherlock (TV series)|Sherlock]]'', is referred to as a psychopath multiple times throughout the course of the show; in response to these claims, Holmes describes himself as a "high-functioning sociopath". He has also been described as having [[Asperger syndrome]].<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/06/magazine/06diagnosis-t.html?pagewanted=2&_r=1&ref=todayspaper</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.planetclaire.org/quotes/sherlock/series-two/the-hounds-of-baskerville/ |title=Sherlock "The Hounds of Baskerville" (Episode 2.2) | Planet Claire Quotes |publisher=Planetclaire.org |date= |accessdate=2014-01-07}}</ref>
The [[Dan Wells (author)|Dan Wells]] novel ''[[I Am Not a Serial Killer]]'' and its sequels, ''[[Mr. Monster]]'' and ''[[I Don't Want To Kill You]]'', are narrated by John Wayne Cleaver, a teenaged diagnosed sociopath who lives by a rigid code of behavior in order to avoid becoming a serial killer.<ref>[http://www.fearfulsymmetry.net/ Author's website]</ref>
One Chicago academic has argued in a review of TV trends that the contemporary fantasy of sociopathy/psychopathy is of someone whose emotional disconnection from others in society, rather than being the hindrance that it can represent in real clinical cases, enables them to be an amazingly successful manipulator due to a breakdown in the [[social contract]].<ref>[http://thenewinquiry.com/features/why-we-love-sociopaths/ Why We Love Sociopaths]. Adam Kotsko, New Inquiry, April 2012</ref>
Contemporary advice on writing psychopathic/sociopathic characters suggests that lack of a conscience and lack of empathy are always the chief characteristics, along with an ability to fool others, while the type of selfish antisocial behavior, and any secondary characteristics, can vary.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=5fPEQl7I5H0C& Bullies, Bastards And Bitches: How To Write The Bad Guys Of Fiction]. Jessica Morrell. 2008. Chapter 7: Sociopaths: Ice in their Veins</ref>
In 2013, the video console game ''[[Grand Theft Auto V]]'' was released with numerous references to psychopaths and sociopaths, including reports from a fictional psychiatrist. One of the lead characters, Trevor, is described both psychopathic and psychotic; the voice actor who played the part says he based his performance on [[Tom Hardy]]'s portrayal of [[Charles Bronson (prisoner)|Charles Bronson]] in the film ''[[Bronson (film)|Bronson]]''.<ref>[https://www.buzzfeed.com/josephbernstein/an-interview-with-steven-ogg-the-voice-of-gta-vs-trevor An Interview With Steven Ogg, The Voice Of "GTA V‚Äôs" Trevor]. September 30, 2013 Joseph Bernstein, BuzzFeed Staff</ref>
[[Jacob M. Appel]]'s ''The Mask of Sanity'' depicts a high-functioning sociopath, Jeremy Balint, who gains fame as a cardiologist while killing strangers.<ref>[http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-1-57962-495-8 Publisher's Weekly]</ref><ref>[https://www.forewordreviews.com/reviews/the-mask-of-sanity/ Review by Jeffrey Fleischer]</ref>.
The character Villanelle in [[Killing Eve]] refers to herself as a [[Killing Eve|psychopath]].<ref>{{Citation|last=Villanelle.|first=Oh, Sandra, 1971- actor. Comer, Jodie, actor. Shaw, Fiona, 1958- actor. Bodnia, Kim, 1965- actor. Waller-Bridge, Phoebe, 1985- screenwriter. Kay, George (Screenwriter), screenwriter. Jones, Vicky (Theatre director), screenwriter. Williams, Rob, (Film director), screenwriter. East, Jon, television director. Thomas, Damon (Director), television director. Bradbeer, Harry, television director. Television adaptation of (work): Jennings, Luke. Codename|title=Killing Eve|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/1049990682|isbn=9786317426689|oclc=1049990682|access-date=2018-11-14}}</ref>. Her character portrays many of the traits from both sociopath and psychopath with a lack of empathy in her methods of murdering her victims or showing any guilt or remorse after the event.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/basics/psychopathy|title=Psychopathy {{!}} Psychology Today|website=Psychology Today|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-14}}</ref>

They became known when it was revealed that the songs they claimed to have written themselves were made by [[demoscene]] musicians and downloaded from micromusic.net, while the two women added their own often explicit lyrics to the music.<ref>[http://www11.nrk.no/urort/article.aspx?articleId=5820022 NRK: Ikke stjel andres l√•ter!]{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070213215821/http://www11.nrk.no/urort/article.aspx?articleId=5820022 |date=13 February 2007 }}</ref> According to micromusic.net they have so far identified songs from 505 of YM Rockerz, Bin√§rpilot, [[8 Bit Weapon]], [[Arachno]], Printed Circuit, Yerzmyey, [[Drx]] of [[Bodenst√§ndig 2000]], [[Jo Petrole]] and [[Stu Drop da Bomb|Stu]] of [[Drop da Bomb]]. After it was made public that they had copied the songs, Fitts for Fight deleted the music from their page on [[MySpace]]<ref>[http://www.vorc.org/en/20061219014954 VORC: Fitts For Fight stealing chip music]{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070105152332/http://www.vorc.org/en/20061219014954 |date=5 January 2007 }}</ref> and they were removed from [[Ur√∏rt]]. Also the [[by:Larm]] festival dropped them from the programme<ref>[http://www.dagbladet.no/kultur/2007/01/15/488924.html Dagbladet: 15-√•ringer f√•r ikke spille p√• Bylarm]. Dagbladet.no (15 January 2007). Retrieved on 12 December 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.fvn.no/kulturpuls/musikk/article423062.ece Fitts for Fight beskyldes for plagiat]. Fvn.no (23 November 2011). Retrieved on 12 December 2011.</ref><ref>{{no icon}} [http://www.ballade.no/nmi.nsf/doc/art2006121310535977289539 MIC: Fitts For Fight ‚Äì DIY eller plagiat?]. Ballade.no (13 December 2006). Retrieved on 12 December 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.adressa.no/kultur/festivaler/bylarm/article787566.ece NTB: Plagierte andre ‚Äì bylarm dumpet] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070211110653/http://www.adressa.no/kultur/festivaler/bylarm/article787566.ece |date=11 February 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{no icon}} [http://www.ballade.no/nmi.nsf/doc/art2007011516051274623941 MIC: by:Larm om Fitts For Fight]. Ballade.no (16 January 2007). Retrieved on 12 December 2011.</ref> and they were replaced by Bin√§rpilot.<ref>{{no icon}} [http://www.ballade.no/nmi.nsf/doc/art2007011513510379930418 MIC: Ingen larm for Fitts For Fight]. Ballade.no (15 January 2007). Retrieved on 12 December 2011.</ref> Examples of music that Fitts for Fight stole are ''Fuck off and die'' that is actually ''STereoid'' by Stu, ''CrashBurnDestroy'' that is ''Space Travel'' by Yerzmyey, and ''Monstermachine'' that is ''Otosclerosis'' by Bin√§rpilot.
[[Stu Drop da Bomb|Stu]] of [[Drop da Bomb]] has been in contact with the Swiss copyright organisation [[SUISA]] who in turn would contact the Norwegian [[TONO]].<ref>{{no icon}} [http://www.ballade.no/nmi.nsf/doc/art2006122110045456290226 MIC: Micromusic vs. Fitts for Fight]. Ballade.no (21 December 2006). Retrieved on 12 December 2011.</ref>

[[File:Galinha Pintadinha.jpg|thumb|200px|Album cover ''Galinha Pintadinha 2'' with the character in focus.]] '''Galinha Pintadinha''', (English translation: Little Dappled Chicken) known also as "Lottie Dottie Chicken"<ref name="Comercial">{{cite news|url=http://reconectar.blog.br/comercial/2013/07/25/galinha-pintadinha-agora-e-internacional-lottie-dottie-chicken-is-now-international/ |title=Lottie Dottie Chicken is now International |publisher=''[[Reconectar]]'' |accessdate=August 27, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006111120/http://reconectar.blog.br/comercial/2013/07/25/galinha-pintadinha-agora-e-internacional-lottie-dottie-chicken-is-now-international/ |archivedate=October 6, 2014 |df= }}</ref> is a [[Brazil]]ian project for children's music, created by Juliano Prado and Marcos Luporini, and animated by ''Bromelia Produ√ß√µes''. The songs are originally in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] and are getting millions of downloads on [[YouTube]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://epoca.globo.com/vida/vida-util/carreira/noticia/2013/10/como-os-criadores-da-bgalinha-pintadinhab-ficaram-milionarios.html|title=Como os criadores da Galinha Pintadinha ficaram milion√°rios|last=Coronato|first=Marcos|author2=Ciscati, Rafael|date=4 October 2013|work=[[√âpoca (Brazilian magazine)|√âpoca]]|language=Portuguese|accessdate=19 October 2013}}</ref> Some of the songs have been already translated into Spanish and English.
==History== The songs revolve around the title character Galinha Pintadinha, a [[cartoon]] chicken and their friends from [[nursery rhyme]]s, in animated music videos made in [[flash animation]]. They were phenomena in DVD sales during the early 2010s to be released and publicized nationally by [[Som Livre]] becoming well known among children with clowns [[Patati Patat√°]]. Also released several products based on the characters as toys, books and apps for smartphones.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.galinhapintadinha.com.br/loja/produtos.html |title=Store |accessdate=26 June 2012 |author=Official website |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120708232047/http://www.galinhapintadinha.com.br/loja/produtos.html |archivedate=8 July 2012 |df= }}</ref> According to [[Associa√ß√£o Brasileira dos Produtores de Discos]], the second DVD was the 6th biggest selling in 2010 DVD and 17th best-selling in 2011 in Brazil.<ref name="Downloads">{{cite news|url=http://www.abpd.org.br/downloads/Fina2011.pdf/ |title=Mercado Brasileiro de M√∫sica 2011 |publisher=''[[Associa√ß√£o Brasileira dos Produtores de Discos|ABPD]]'' |accessdate=August 27, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141014073225/http://abpd.org.br/downloads/Fina2011.pdf |archivedate=October 14, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
In 2013 the animated music videos premiered on [[Netflix]] in several countries including in the [[United States]], [[Canada]] and Spanish Latin American countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://info.abril.com.br/noticias/internet/2015/07/galinha-pintadinha-chega-ao-netflix-dos-estados-unidos-e-de-paises-de-lingua-espanhola.shtml |title=Galinha Pintadinha estreia na Netflix dos Estados Unidos e de pa√≠ses de l√≠ngua espanhola |accessdate=11 September 2015|author=Info Abril}}</ref> In 2015 his studio occupied the 89th position as one of the 150 biggest licensed brands in the world, ranking published by the British magazine ''License! Global''.<ref>http://www.licensemag.com/license-global/top-150-global-licensors-1?page=0,11</ref> ==Media== Since the release of their second album the character had a pretty big growth in children's media in Brazil. Many toys, backpacks, CDs, books and supplies for babies have been launched over the years. The characters also have achieved media for Smartphones with music applications and interactive games such as ''PoChickenPo''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.techtudo.com.br/tudo-sobre/galinha-pintadinha-no-android.html|title=Galinha Pintadinha no Android| publisher=Techtudo|accessdate=September 17, 2014}}</ref>

'''The Grand Master of Magic¬Æ Award''' is a lifetime achievement award presented by the Brotherhood of Auckland Magicians Incorporated on behalf of the magicians of New Zealand. It was first awarded in 1969 and to date it has been awarded on eighteen occasions.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://bam.net.nz/grand-masters-of-magic/|title=Brotherhood of Auckland Magicians : Grand Master of Magic Award information}}</ref><ref name="ibmring160">{{cite web|url=http://ibmring160.com/national-awards/grand-masters.aspx|title=Grand Master of Magic criteria}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://geniimagazine.com/magicpedia/Edgar_Benyon|title=Benyon Biography, MagicPedia}}</ref>
== Criteria for the Grand Master of Magic¬Æ ==
The criteria for the Grand Master of Magic Award was formalised in 1998 and is as follows :
"Its purpose is to honour those magicians who are acknowledged by their fellow magicians to be masters of the art and craft of [[Magic (illusion)|magic]]. The recipients first and foremost must be [[performers]] of a high standard. In addition they might be originators of [[magic tricks|magical effects]], or administrators giving time and expertise to running societies and [[magic convention|conventions]]. They could be consistent competition winners, or have an international standing, or be known only in the [[New Zealand]] setting. But above all they are people who have served magic well, have graced our art, and made a special contribution over many years."
Any nomination must also be measured against the standard achieved by the previous recipients.<ref name="auto"/><ref name="ibmring160" />
